spans.text: CHAPTER 3 RURAL SETTLEMENT AND URBAN SETTLEMENT
The minimum number of people needed to maintain a
The maximum distance people are prepared to travel to a
The maximum area served by a settlement or function
Trade and transport towns or cities
These are towns or cities which develop at a point where transport routes
meet. Easy access to trade and transport in the area is the reason why
There are three types of trade and transport cities:
: They develop at a point where the
type of transport changes. This is most often at a harbour where the
transport changes from sea to land.
: They develop at an intersection of two major
transport routes, for example a railway junction.
: They develop at a point of access through or
over a physical barrier, for example at a mountain pass.
These are towns or cities which have developed because of one main
or dominant function occurring in the area. If the function were to stop
then the city would be at risk of becoming a ghost town (a deserted town).
Examples of specialised towns or cities are:
Mining towns or cities, e.g. Welkom
Education towns or cities, e.g. Grahamstown
Industrial towns or cities, e.g. Secunda, Sasolburg
Resort towns or cities, e.g. Margate
Dormitory or commuter towns or cities, e.g. Soweto
In an exam, you may be asked to identify the type of trade and transport city in a
diagram. If a key is given, look at it carefully to help you answer the question. Learn the
information above to help you answer this question.

Chapters.Title: 54  CHAPTER
Text:
of Basic Education 2014
54  CHAPTER 3 RURAL SETTLEMENT AND URBAN SETTLEMENT 
Mind the Gap CAPS Grade 12 Geography
Chapter
3
Answers to activity 3.3
1. 
KEY:
 Settlement or function33
Sphere of influence33
Range33
Threshold population33
Figure 3.3.2B
2. a)  The minimum number of people needed to maintain a 
settlement or function33 
(2)
b) The maximum distance people are prepared to travel to a 
settlement or a function33 
(2)
c) The maximum area served by a settlement or function33 (2)
[12]
Trade and transport towns or cities
These are towns or cities which develop at a point where transport routes 
meet. Easy access to trade and transport in the area is the reason why 
people settle there.
There are three types of trade and transport cities:
â¢ 
Break-of-bulk towns or cities: They develop at a point where the 
type of transport changes. This is most often at a harbour where the 
transport changes from sea to land.
â¢ 
Junction towns or cities: They develop at an intersection of two major 
transport routes, for example a railway junction.
â¢ 
Gap towns or cities: They develop at a point of access through or 
over a physical barrier, for example at a mountain pass.
Specialised towns or cities
These are towns or cities which have developed because of one main  
or dominant function occurring in the area. If the function were to stop 
then the city would be at risk of becoming a ghost town (a deserted town). 
Examples of specialised towns or cities are:
â¢ 
Mining towns or cities, e.g. Welkom
â¢ 
Education towns or cities, e.g. Grahamstown
â¢ 
Industrial towns or cities, e.g. Secunda, Sasolburg
â¢ 
Resort towns or cities, e.g. Margate
â¢ 
Dormitory or commuter towns or cities, e.g. Soweto
In an exam, you may be asked to identify the type of trade and transport city in a 
diagram. If a key is given, look at it carefully to help you answer the question. Learn the 
information above to help you answer this question.
